# HTTPS listener
listener "tcp" {
  address       = "0.0.0.0:8200"
  tls_cert_file = "/opt/vault/tls/tls.crt"
  tls_key_file  = "/opt/vault/tls/tls.key"
}

# HTTP listener (disable in production)
listener "tcp" {
  address     = "127.0.0.1:8201"
  tls_disable = true
}

# Enterprise license (if applicable)
# license_path = "/etc/vault.d/vault.hclic"

# API address
api_addr = "https://127.0.0.1:8200"

# Cluster address  
cluster_addr = "https://127.0.0.1:8201"

# Logging
log_level = "INFO"
log_file  = "/var/log/vault/vault.log"
EOF

# Create data directory
sudo mkdir -p /opt/vault/{data,tls}
sudo chown -R vault:vault /opt/vault

# Create log directory
sudo mkdir -p /var/log/vault
sudo chown vault:vault /var/log/vault

    SSL/TLS Certificate Setup

    bash 
    # Generate self-signed certificate for development
sudo openssl req -x509 -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 \
  -keyout /opt/vault/tls/tls.key \
  -out /opt/vault/tls/tls.crt \
  -subj "/C=US/ST=State/L=City/O=Organization/CN=vault.example.com"

sudo chown vault:vault /opt/vault/tls/*
sudo chmod 600 /opt/vault/tls/tls.key
sudo chmod 644 /opt/vault/tls/tls.crt

# For production, use Let's Encrypt
sudo apt install -y certbot
sudo certbot certonly --standalone -d vault.example.com
sudo cp /etc/letsencrypt/live/vault.example.com/fullchain.pem /opt/vault/tls/tls.crt
sudo cp /etc/letsencrypt/live/vault.example.com/privkey.pem /opt/vault/tls/tls.key
sudo chown vault:vault /opt/vault/tls/*

    SystemD Service

    bash 
    # Create systemd service
sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/vault.service > /dev/null <<EOF
[Unit]
Description="HashiCorp Vault - A tool for managing secrets"
Documentation=https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/
Requires=network-online.target
After=network-online.target
ConditionFileNotEmpty=/etc/vault.d/vault.hcl
StartLimitIntervalSec=60
StartLimitBurst=3

[Service]
Type=notify
User=vault
Group=vault
ProtectSystem=full
ProtectHome=read-only
PrivateTmp=yes
PrivateDevices=yes
SecureBits=keep-caps
AmbientCapabilities=CAP_IPC_LOCK
CapabilityBoundingSet=CAP_SYSLOG CAP_IPC_LOCK
NoNewPrivileges=yes
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/vault server -config=/etc/vault.d/vault.hcl
ExecReload=/bin/kill --signal HUP $MAINPID
KillMode=process
Restart=on-failure
RestartSec=5
TimeoutStopSec=30
StartLimitInterval=60
StartLimitBurst=3
LimitNOFILE=65536
LimitMEMLOCK=infinity

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF

# Enable and start Vault
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable --now vault

    Initial Setup and Unsealing

    bash 
    # Initialize Vault (one-time setup)
export VAULT_ADDR='http://127.0.0.1:8200'
vault operator init

# Save the unseal keys and root token securely!
# Example output:
# Unseal Key 1: key1...
# Unseal Key 2: key2...
# Unseal Key 3: key3...
# Initial Root Token: hvs.token...

# Unseal Vault (required after every restart)
vault operator unseal KEY1
vault operator unseal KEY2  
vault operator unseal KEY3

# Login with root token
vault auth ROOT_TOKEN

# Check status
vault status

    Basic Usage

    Authentication Methods

    bash 
    # Enable userpass authentication
vault auth enable userpass

# Create user
vault write auth/userpass/users/admin password=secure_password policies=admin

# Enable GitHub authentication
vault auth enable github
vault write auth/github/config organization=your-org

# Login with different methods
vault auth -method=userpass username=admin
vault auth -method=github token=github_token

    Secrets Management

    bash 
    # Enable KV secrets engine
vault secrets enable -version=2 kv

# Store secrets
vault kv put secret/myapp/config \
  username=admin \
  password=secure_password \
  api_key=abc123

# Read secrets
vault kv get secret/myapp/config
vault kv get -field=password secret/myapp/config

# Update secrets
vault kv put secret/myapp/config \
  username=admin \
  password=new_password \
  api_key=def456

# Delete secrets
vault kv delete secret/myapp/config

# List secrets
vault kv list secret/

    Policies

    bash 
    # Create policy file
cat > admin-policy.hcl <<EOF
# Admin policy
path "*" {
  capabilities = ["create", "read", "update", "delete", "list", "sudo"]
}
EOF

# Apply policy
vault policy write admin admin-policy.hcl

# Create read-only policy
cat > readonly-policy.hcl <<EOF
# Read-only access to secrets
path "secret/data/*" {
  capabilities = ["read", "list"]
}
EOF

vault policy write readonly readonly-policy.hcl

# List policies
vault policy list
vault policy read admin

    Database Secrets Engine

    bash 
    # Enable database secrets engine
vault secrets enable database

# Configure MySQL connection
vault write database/config/mysql \
  plugin_name=mysql-database-plugin \
  connection_url="{{username}}:{{password}}@tcp(mysql.example.com:3306)/" \
  allowed_roles="mysql-role" \
  username="vault" \
  password="vault-password"

# Create role for dynamic credentials
vault write database/roles/mysql-role \
  db_name=mysql \
  creation_statements="CREATE USER '{{name}}'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY '{{password}}';GRANT SELECT ON *.* TO '{{name}}'@'%';" \
  default_ttl="1h" \
  max_ttl="24h"

# Generate dynamic credentials
vault read database/creds/mysql-role

    High Availability Setup

    Consul Backend

    bash 
    # Install Consul
sudo apt install -y consul

# Configure Vault with Consul backend
sudo tee /etc/vault.d/vault-ha.hcl > /dev/null <<EOF
ui = true
disable_mlock = true

storage "consul" {
  address = "127.0.0.1:8500"
  path    = "vault/"
}

listener "tcp" {
  address     = "0.0.0.0:8200"
  tls_cert_file = "/opt/vault/tls/tls.crt"
  tls_key_file  = "/opt/vault/tls/tls.key"
}

api_addr = "https://vault-1.example.com:8200"
cluster_addr = "https://vault-1.example.com:8201"
EOF

    Backup and Recovery

    bash 
    # Create backup script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/vault-backup.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
BACKUP_DIR="/backup/vault"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p ${BACKUP_DIR}

# Create snapshot (Enterprise feature)
# vault operator raft snapshot save ${BACKUP_DIR}/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap

# For OSS version, backup storage backend data
if [ -d "/opt/vault/data" ]; then
    tar -czf ${BACKUP_DIR}/vault-data-${DATE}.tar.gz -C /opt/vault data
fi

# Keep only last 7 backups
find ${BACKUP_DIR} -name "vault-*-*.tar.gz" -type f -mtime +7 -delete

echo "Backup completed: vault-data-${DATE}.tar.gz"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/vault-backup.sh

# Schedule daily backup
echo "0 2 * * * root /usr/local/bin/vault-backup.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab

    Firewall Configuration

    bash 
    # UFW (Ubuntu/Debian)
sudo ufw allow 8200/tcp   # Vault API
sudo ufw allow 8201/tcp   # Vault cluster communication
sudo ufw enable

# Firewalld (RHEL/CentOS)
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --add-port=8200/tcp
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --add-port=8201/tcp
sudo firewall-cmd --reload

    Verification

    bash 
    # Check Vault status
vault status

# Check systemd service
sudo systemctl status vault

# Test API connectivity
curl -s http://127.0.0.1:8200/v1/sys/health | jq

# Check authentication methods
vault auth list

# Check secrets engines
vault secrets list

# Check policies
vault policy list

# Check audit devices
vault audit list

# View server logs
sudo journalctl -u vault -f

# Check seal status
vault operator key-status

    Security Best Practices

    bash 
    # Enable audit logging
vault audit enable file file_path=/var/log/vault/audit.log

# Create separate policies for different roles
cat > developer-policy.hcl <<EOF
# Developers can read/write to dev secrets
path "secret/data/dev/*" {
  capabilities = ["create", "read", "update", "delete", "list"]
}

# Read-only access to shared secrets
path "secret/data/shared/*" {
  capabilities = ["read", "list"]
}
EOF

vault policy write developer developer-policy.hcl

# Set up auto-unseal with cloud KMS (production)
# AWS KMS example
vault write sys/config/seal/awskms \
  region="us-west-2" \
  access_key="YOUR_ACCESS_KEY" \
  secret_key="YOUR_SECRET_KEY" \
  kms_key_id="alias/vault-unseal-key"

# Enable periodic token renewal
vault write auth/token/roles/auto-renew \
  allowed_policies="developer" \
  orphan=true \
  period="24h" \
  renewable=true

    Integration Examples

    Application Integration

    bash 
    # Using Vault Agent for automatic authentication
cat > /etc/vault-agent.hcl <<EOF
exit_after_auth = false
pid_file = "./pidfile"

auto_auth {
  method "aws" {
    mount_path = "auth/aws"
    config = {
      type = "iam"
      role = "vault-role"
    }
  }

  sink "file" {
    config = {
      path = "/tmp/vault-token-via-agent"
    }
  }
}

cache {
  use_auto_auth_token = true
}

listener "tcp" {
  address = "127.0.0.1:8100"
  tls_disable = true
}

template {
  source      = "/opt/vault/templates/config.json.tpl"
  destination = "/opt/app/config.json"
  perms       = 0640
  command     = "systemctl reload myapp"
}
EOF

# Start Vault Agent
vault agent -config=/etc/vault-agent.hcl

    Kubernetes Integration

    bash 
    # Enable Kubernetes auth method
vault auth enable kubernetes

# Configure Kubernetes auth
vault write auth/kubernetes/config \
  token_reviewer_jwt="$(cat /var/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/token)" \
  kubernetes_host=https://${KUBERNETES_PORT_443_TCP_ADDR}:443 \
  kubernetes_ca_cert=@/var/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/ca.crt

# Create role for Kubernetes service accounts
vault write auth/kubernetes/role/myapp \
  bound_service_account_names=vault \
  bound_service_account_namespaces=default \
  policies=myapp-policy \
  ttl=24h

    Troubleshooting

    bash 
    # Check Vault logs
sudo journalctl -u vault -f

# Debug mode
sudo systemctl stop vault
sudo -u vault vault server -config=/etc/vault.d/vault.hcl -log-level=debug

# Check seal status
vault operator key-status

# Check storage backend
vault operator raft list-peers  # For raft storage
consul kv get -recurse vault/   # For consul storage

# Test connectivity
curl -s http://127.0.0.1:8200/v1/sys/health

# Check performance
vault operator usage

# Rotate encryption key
vault operator rotate

# Check configuration
vault operator diagnose -config=/etc/vault.d/vault.hcl

    Additional Resources

  • Official Documentation
  • API Documentation
  • Best Practices
  • Vault Guides
  • Community Forum

    • ---

    Note: This guide is part of the HowToMgr collection.

guides.name: wordpress
guides.readmeRaw:
# WordPress Installation Guide

Popular content management system (CMS) for creating websites, blogs, and web applications with a user-friendly interface.

## Prerequisites

- Linux system (Ubuntu/Debian, RHEL/CentOS, or compatible)
- Web server (Apache or NGINX)
- PHP 7.4+ with required extensions
- MySQL 5.7+ or PostgreSQL 9.6+
- SSL certificate (recommended)

## Installation

### LAMP Stack Setup (Apache + MySQL + PHP)
```bash
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y apache2 mysql-server php php-mysql php-curl php-gd php-mbstring php-xml php-xmlrpc php-soap php-intl php-zip

# RHEL/CentOS
sudo yum install -y httpd mariadb-server php php-mysql php-curl php-gd php-mbstring php-xml php-xmlrpc php-soap php-intl php-zip

# Enable services
sudo systemctl enable --now apache2 mysql  # Ubuntu/Debian
sudo systemctl enable --now httpd mariadb  # RHEL/CentOS
```

### LEMP Stack Setup (NGINX + MySQL + PHP)
```bash
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y nginx mysql-server php-fpm php-mysql php-curl php-gd php-mbstring php-xml php-xmlrpc php-soap php-intl php-zip

# RHEL/CentOS  
sudo yum install -y nginx mariadb-server php-fpm php-mysql php-curl php-gd php-mbstring php-xml php-xmlrpc php-soap php-intl php-zip

# Enable services
sudo systemctl enable --now nginx mysql php7.4-fpm  # Ubuntu/Debian
sudo systemctl enable --now nginx mariadb php-fpm   # RHEL/CentOS
```

### Database Setup
```bash
# Secure MySQL installation
sudo mysql_secure_installation

# Create WordPress database
sudo mysql -u root -p <<EOF
CREATE DATABASE wordpress DEFAULT CHARACTER SET utf8 COLLATE utf8_unicode_ci;
CREATE USER 'wordpressuser'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'secure_password';
GRANT ALL ON wordpress.* TO 'wordpressuser'@'localhost';
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;
EXIT
EOF
```

### WordPress Download and Setup
```bash
# Download WordPress
cd /tmp
wget https://wordpress.org/latest.tar.gz
tar xzf latest.tar.gz

# Create document root and copy files
sudo mkdir -p /var/www/html/wordpress
sudo cp -R /tmp/wordpress/* /var/www/html/wordpress/
sudo chown -R www-data:www-data /var/www/html/wordpress  # Ubuntu/Debian
sudo chown -R apache:apache /var/www/html/wordpress      # RHEL/CentOS

# Set proper permissions
sudo find /var/www/html/wordpress/ -type d -exec chmod 755 {} \;
sudo find /var/www/html/wordpress/ -type f -exec chmod 644 {} \;

# Create wp-config.php
cd /var/www/html/wordpress
sudo cp wp-config-sample.php wp-config.php

# Generate salt keys
curl -s https://api.wordpress.org/secret-key/1.1/salt/

# Edit wp-config.php with database details and salt keys
sudo nano wp-config.php
```

## Configuration

### Apache Virtual Host
```bash
# Create Apache virtual host
sudo tee /etc/apache2/sites-available/wordpress.conf > /dev/null <<EOF
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName wordpress.example.com
    ServerAlias www.wordpress.example.com
    DocumentRoot /var/www/html/wordpress
    
    <Directory /var/www/html/wordpress/>
        AllowOverride All
        Options -Indexes +FollowSymLinks
        Require all granted
    </Directory>
    
    # Security headers
    Header always set X-Frame-Options SAMEORIGIN
    Header always set X-Content-Type-Options nosniff
    Header always set X-XSS-Protection "1; mode=block"
    Header always set Referrer-Policy "strict-origin-when-cross-origin"
    
    # Hide PHP version
    Header always unset X-Powered-By
    
    # Disable server signature
    ServerSignature Off
    
    ErrorLog \${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/wordpress_error.log
    CustomLog \${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/wordpress_access.log combined
</VirtualHost>
EOF

# Enable modules and site
sudo a2enmod rewrite headers ssl
sudo a2ensite wordpress.conf
sudo systemctl restart apache2
```

### NGINX Configuration
```bash
# Create NGINX server block
sudo tee /etc/nginx/sites-available/wordpress > /dev/null <<EOF
server {
    listen 80;
    server_name wordpress.example.com www.wordpress.example.com;
    root /var/www/html/wordpress;
    index index.php index.html index.htm;

    # Security headers
    add_header X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN" always;
    add_header X-XSS-Protection "1; mode=block" always;
    add_header X-Content-Type-Options "nosniff" always;
    add_header Referrer-Policy "no-referrer-when-downgrade" always;
    add_header Content-Security-Policy "default-src 'self' http: https: data: blob: 'unsafe-inline'" always;

    # Hide nginx version
    server_tokens off;

    # WordPress specific rules
    location / {
        try_files \$uri \$uri/ /index.php?\$args;
    }

    location ~ \.php\$ {
        include snippets/fastcgi-php.conf;
        fastcgi_pass unix:/var/run/php/php7.4-fpm.sock;  # Adjust PHP version
        fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME \$document_root\$fastcgi_script_name;
        include fastcgi_params;
    }

    # Security rules
    location ~* /(?:uploads|files)/.*\.php\$ {
        deny all;
    }

    location ~* \.(js|css|png|jpg|jpeg|gif|ico|svg)\$ {
        expires 1y;
        add_header Cache-Control "public, immutable";
    }

    # Deny access to sensitive files
    location ~* \.(htaccess|htpasswd|ini|log|sh|inc|bak)\$ {
        deny all;
    }

    # WordPress: deny wp-config.php access
    location ~* wp-config\.php {
        deny all;
    }

    # WordPress: deny general stuff
    location ~* ^/(\.user.ini|php.ini|\..*)$ {
        deny all;
    }
}
EOF

# Enable site
sudo ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/wordpress /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/
sudo nginx -t && sudo systemctl restart nginx
```

### WordPress Configuration (wp-config.php)
```bash
# Create secure wp-config.php
sudo tee /var/www/html/wordpress/wp-config.php > /dev/null <<'EOF'
<?php
// Database settings
define('DB_NAME', 'wordpress');
define('DB_USER', 'wordpressuser');
define('DB_PASSWORD', 'secure_password');
define('DB_HOST', 'localhost');
define('DB_CHARSET', 'utf8mb4');
define('DB_COLLATE', '');

// Authentication Unique Keys and Salts
// Generate these at: https://api.wordpress.org/secret-key/1.1/salt/
define('AUTH_KEY',         'put your unique phrase here');
define('SECURE_AUTH_KEY',  'put your unique phrase here');
define('LOGGED_IN_KEY',    'put your unique phrase here');
define('NONCE_KEY',        'put your unique phrase here');
define('AUTH_SALT',        'put your unique phrase here');
define('SECURE_AUTH_SALT', 'put your unique phrase here');
define('LOGGED_IN_SALT',   'put your unique phrase here');
define('NONCE_SALT',       'put your unique phrase here');

// WordPress Database Table prefix
$table_prefix = 'wp_';

// WordPress debug mode (disable in production)
define('WP_DEBUG', false);

// Security enhancements
define('DISALLOW_FILE_EDIT', true);
define('DISALLOW_FILE_MODS', true);
define('FORCE_SSL_ADMIN', true);
define('WP_AUTO_UPDATE_CORE', true);

// Increase memory limit
define('WP_MEMORY_LIMIT', '512M');

// Custom content directory (optional)
define('WP_CONTENT_DIR', '/var/www/html/wordpress/wp-content');
define('WP_CONTENT_URL', 'https://wordpress.example.com/wp-content');

// Automatic updates
define('WP_AUTO_UPDATE_CORE', 'minor');

/* That's all, stop editing! Happy publishing. */
if ( ! defined( 'ABSPATH' ) ) {
    define( 'ABSPATH', dirname( __FILE__ ) . '/' );
}

require_once ABSPATH . 'wp-settings.php';
EOF

sudo chown www-data:www-data /var/www/html/wordpress/wp-config.php
sudo chmod 600 /var/www/html/wordpress/wp-config.php
```

### SSL Configuration with Let's Encrypt
```bash
# Install Certbot
sudo apt install -y certbot python3-certbot-apache  # For Apache
sudo apt install -y certbot python3-certbot-nginx   # For NGINX

# Obtain SSL certificate
sudo certbot --apache -d wordpress.example.com -d www.wordpress.example.com  # Apache
sudo certbot --nginx -d wordpress.example.com -d www.wordpress.example.com   # NGINX

# Auto-renewal
sudo crontab -e
# Add: 0 12 * * * /usr/bin/certbot renew --quiet
```

## Performance Optimization

### PHP Optimization
```bash
# Edit PHP configuration
sudo nano /etc/php/7.4/apache2/php.ini  # Apache
sudo nano /etc/php/7.4/fpm/php.ini      # NGINX

# Recommended settings:
memory_limit = 512M
post_max_size = 128M
upload_max_filesize = 128M
max_execution_time = 300
max_input_time = 300
max_input_vars = 3000
date.timezone = "America/New_York"

# Enable OPcache
opcache.enable = 1
opcache.memory_consumption = 128
opcache.interned_strings_buffer = 8
opcache.max_accelerated_files = 4000
opcache.revalidate_freq = 2
opcache.fast_shutdown = 1

sudo systemctl restart apache2  # Apache
sudo systemctl restart php7.4-fpm nginx  # NGINX
```

### WordPress Caching
```bash
# Install Redis for object caching
sudo apt install -y redis-server
sudo systemctl enable --now redis-server

# Configure Redis
sudo tee -a /etc/redis/redis.conf > /dev/null <<EOF
maxmemory 256mb
maxmemory-policy allkeys-lru
EOF

sudo systemctl restart redis-server

# Install WordPress Redis plugin via WP-CLI
cd /var/www/html/wordpress
curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/wp-cli/builds/gh-pages/phar/wp-cli.phar
chmod +x wp-cli.phar
sudo mv wp-cli.phar /usr/local/bin/wp

# Install and configure Redis plugin
sudo -u www-data wp plugin install redis-cache --activate
sudo -u www-data wp redis enable

# Install caching plugins
sudo -u www-data wp plugin install w3-total-cache --activate
sudo -u www-data wp plugin install wp-super-cache --activate
```

### Database Optimization
```bash
# Optimize MySQL for WordPress
sudo tee -a /etc/mysql/mysql.conf.d/mysqld.cnf > /dev/null <<EOF

# WordPress optimizations
innodb_buffer_pool_size = 1G
innodb_log_file_size = 256M
innodb_log_buffer_size = 8M
innodb_file_per_table = 1
innodb_open_files = 400
innodb_io_capacity = 400
```

## Backup and Maintenance

### Automated Backup Script
```bash
# Create backup script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/wordpress-backup.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
BACKUP_DIR="/backup/wordpress"
WP_DIR="/var/www/html/wordpress"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p ${BACKUP_DIR}/{files,database}

# Backup WordPress files
tar -czf ${BACKUP_DIR}/files/wordpress-files-${DATE}.tar.gz -C ${WP_DIR} .

# Backup database
mysqldump -u wordpressuser -p'secure_password' wordpress > ${BACKUP_DIR}/database/wordpress-db-${DATE}.sql
gzip ${BACKUP_DIR}/database/wordpress-db-${DATE}.sql

# Using WP-CLI for database export
cd ${WP_DIR}
sudo -u www-data wp db export ${BACKUP_DIR}/database/wordpress-wpcli-${DATE}.sql
gzip ${BACKUP_DIR}/database/wordpress-wpcli-${DATE}.sql

# Keep only last 7 backups
find ${BACKUP_DIR} -name "wordpress-*" -type f -mtime +7 -delete

echo "Backup completed: wordpress-${DATE}"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/wordpress-backup.sh

# Schedule daily backup
echo "0 2 * * * root /usr/local/bin/wordpress-backup.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab
```

### Maintenance Tasks
```bash
# Create maintenance script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/wordpress-maintenance.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
WP_DIR="/var/www/html/wordpress"
cd ${WP_DIR}

# Update WordPress core, plugins, and themes
sudo -u www-data wp core update
sudo -u www-data wp plugin update --all
sudo -u www-data wp theme update --all

# Database cleanup
sudo -u www-data wp transient delete --all
sudo -u www-data wp db optimize

# Clear caches
if sudo -u www-data wp plugin is-installed w3-total-cache; then
    sudo -u www-data wp w3-total-cache flush all
fi

if sudo -u www-data wp plugin is-installed wp-super-cache; then
    sudo -u www-data wp super-cache flush
fi

echo "WordPress maintenance completed"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/wordpress-maintenance.sh

# Schedule weekly maintenance
echo "0 3 * * 0 root /usr/local/bin/wordpress-maintenance.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab
```

BACKUP_DIR="/backup/wordpress"
WP_DIR="/var/www/html/wordpress"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p ${BACKUP_DIR}/{files,database}

# Backup WordPress files
tar -czf ${BACKUP_DIR}/files/wordpress-files-${DATE}.tar.gz -C ${WP_DIR} .

# Backup database
mysqldump -u wordpressuser -p'secure_password' wordpress > ${BACKUP_DIR}/database/wordpress-db-${DATE}.sql
gzip ${BACKUP_DIR}/database/wordpress-db-${DATE}.sql

# Using WP-CLI for database export
cd ${WP_DIR}
sudo -u www-data wp db export ${BACKUP_DIR}/database/wordpress-wpcli-${DATE}.sql
gzip ${BACKUP_DIR}/database/wordpress-wpcli-${DATE}.sql

# Keep only last 7 backups
find ${BACKUP_DIR} -name "wordpress-*" -type f -mtime +7 -delete

echo "Backup completed: wordpress-${DATE}"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/wordpress-backup.sh

# Schedule daily backup
echo "0 2 * * * root /usr/local/bin/wordpress-backup.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab

    Maintenance Tasks

    bash 
    # Create maintenance script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/wordpress-maintenance.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
WP_DIR="/var/www/html/wordpress"
cd ${WP_DIR}

# Update WordPress core, plugins, and themes
sudo -u www-data wp core update
sudo -u www-data wp plugin update --all
sudo -u www-data wp theme update --all

# Database cleanup
sudo -u www-data wp transient delete --all
sudo -u www-data wp db optimize

# Clear caches
if sudo -u www-data wp plugin is-installed w3-total-cache; then
    sudo -u www-data wp w3-total-cache flush all
fi

if sudo -u www-data wp plugin is-installed wp-super-cache; then
    sudo -u www-data wp super-cache flush
fi

echo "WordPress maintenance completed"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/wordpress-maintenance.sh

# Schedule weekly maintenance
echo "0 3 * * 0 root /usr/local/bin/wordpress-maintenance.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab

    Verification

    bash 
    # Check web server status
sudo systemctl status apache2  # or nginx
sudo systemctl status mysql

# Check PHP-FPM (if using NGINX)
sudo systemctl status php7.4-fpm

# Test database connection
mysql -u wordpressuser -p -e "SHOW DATABASES;"

# Test website
curl -I http://wordpress.example.com

# Check WordPress status via WP-CLI
cd /var/www/html/wordpress
sudo -u www-data wp core version
sudo -u www-data wp plugin status
sudo -u www-data wp theme status

# Check file permissions
ls -la /var/www/html/wordpress/
ls -la /var/www/html/wordpress/wp-content/

# Test uploads directory
sudo -u www-data wp media regenerate --yes

# Check for WordPress updates
sudo -u www-data wp core check-update
sudo -u www-data wp plugin list --update=available

    Troubleshooting

    bash 
    # Enable WordPress debug mode
sudo nano /var/www/html/wordpress/wp-config.php
# Add: define('WP_DEBUG', true);
# Add: define('WP_DEBUG_LOG', true);

# Check WordPress debug log
tail -f /var/www/html/wordpress/wp-content/debug.log

# Check web server logs
sudo tail -f /var/log/apache2/wordpress_error.log  # Apache
sudo tail -f /var/log/nginx/error.log              # NGINX

# Check PHP logs
sudo tail -f /var/log/php7.4-fpm.log

# Database connectivity test
sudo -u www-data wp db check

# Plugin conflict troubleshooting
sudo -u www-data wp plugin deactivate --all
sudo -u www-data wp plugin activate plugin-name

# Theme troubleshooting
sudo -u www-data wp theme activate twentytwentythree

# Check disk space
df -h /var/www/html/wordpress/

# File permission issues
sudo chown -R www-data:www-data /var/www/html/wordpress/
sudo find /var/www/html/wordpress/ -type d -exec chmod 755 {} \;
sudo find /var/www/html/wordpress/ -type f -exec chmod 644 {} \;

# Reset user password via WP-CLI
sudo -u www-data wp user update admin --user_pass=new_password

    Additional Resources

  • WordPress Codex
  • WP-CLI Documentation
  • WordPress Security Guide
  • Performance Best Practices
  • WordPress Forums

# xen-orchestra - CentOS

```bash
curl --silent --location https://rpm.nodesource.com/setup_8.x | sudo bash -
curl --silent --location https://dl.yarnpkg.com/rpm/yarn.repo | sudo tee /etc/yum.repos.d/yarn.repo

yum groupinstall 'Development Tools'
yum -y install epel-release gcc gcc-c++ automake libpng-devel git python redis nodejs yarn
systemctl enable --now redis

git clone -b master http://github.com/vatesfr/xen-orchestra
yarn
yarn build
cd packages/xo-server
cp sample.config.yaml .xo-server.yaml
vi .xo-server.yaml # mounts: '/': '../xo-web/dist/'
yarn start 
```

## xen-orchestra - Debian

```bash
curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_8.x | sudo -E bash -
curl -sS https://dl.yarnpkg.com/debian/pubkey.gpg | sudo apt-key add -
echo "deb https://dl.yarnpkg.com/debian/ stable main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/yarn.list
sudo apt update
sudo apt-get install -y nodejs yarn build-essential redis-server libpng-dev git python-minimal libvhdi-utils lvm2

git clone -b master http://github.com/vatesfr/xen-orchestra
cd xen-orchestra
yarn
yarn build
cd packages/xo-server
cp sample.config.yaml .xo-server.yaml
vi .xo-server.yaml # mounts: '/': '../xo-web/dist/'
yarn start 
```

## xen-orchestra - Updating

```bash
cd /opt/xen-orchestra/
sudo git pull --ff-only
sudo yarn
sudo yarn build
```
